Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Assessing and Quantifying Resilience of Commercial Sectors to Natural Hazards
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research to assess and quantify the resilience of commercial buildings to natural hazards such as earthquakes. Up to this point, most attempts at understanding community resilience have focused on qualitatively assessing resilience in a broad over aching manner. While these methods are valuable they lack the ability to give stakeholders and decision makers specific information for planning and preparing for a disaster. The 2011 Christchurch earthquake caused severe damage to the Christchurch Central Business District (CDB). Studying the impact of the earthquake on the commercial buildings and the recovery decisions currently being made will be a valuable resource for understanding the impacts of future earthquakes in the United States. This project will provide a resilience metric specific for commercial buildings and the tools required to quantitatively measure resilience over time, providing predictive tools that can be used to understand vulnerabilities of commercial buildings, approximate damages and downtimes, and estimate recovery decisions. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Ken Elwood, at the University of Auckland in Auckland, New Zealand.

The impacts of the February 2011 Earthquake in Christchurch, New Zealand, will serve as a case study to develop tools that can be used to assess vulnerabilities of commercial buildings and help predict future outcomes to communities similarly prone to natural hazards. The research will progress in three phases. The first phase is gathering and combining data previously collected in New Zealand and collecting additional data needed for the analysis. During the second phase fault trees and event trees, tools used in risk analysis, will be created to determine system failures, critical baseline events, and possible event sequences in the recovery process. Finally, the fault and event trees will be used to quantify community resilience by determining functionality over time, feeding into the developed resilience metric(s). The final product will be fault trees and event trees to be used by decision makers and engineers to predict potential damages from future earthquakes. This award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to understand how physical damages to buildings impacted the operability and functionality of organizations and buildings following the 2011 Christchurch earthquake. Through understanding the impacts of the physical damage, it becomes possible to not only define resilience of a community, but also to quantity the resilience. Past earthquakes have shown that our building population is vulnerable and at risk to be severely damaged during an earthquake. While the death count is usually low in areas that have high seismic standards in the building code, the extensive damage that still occurs in buildings has prolonged impacts on the organizations in the buildings and the community as a whole. The 2011 Christchurch earthquake is an example of the lengthy recovery time that can be expected after a major earthquake. Christchurch also provides a wealth of information on damages to buildings, impacts to organizations, and recovery decisions. This information can be extremely usefully stakeholders in other communities to best prepare for future earthquakes. This project works towards quantifying the resilience of Christchurch following the earthquake in terms of both building performance (tagging) and continued operability of organizations. Research in this project was undertaken in New Zealand under the direction of Dr. Kenneth Elwood at the University of Auckland.

 

To begin to understand the impacts of the Christchurch earthquake and start quantifying the resilience, extensive time was spent in New Zealand collecting data on the performance of buildings and organizations following the Christchurch earthquake. The first part of the trip was spent determining what data was collected following the earthquake, which owned the data and what the requirements were for obtaining access to the data. The principal research also spent extensive time meeting with government officials, university researchers, facility managers, engineering firms, and private organizations to discuss research goals and obtain access to the data. Data was collected on the physical damage to buildings and the safety placard placement from the initial safety assessments conducted immediately following the earthquake. Further information on how some businesses and organizations within the affected region of Christchurch were impacted by the earthquake was also collected. The remainder of the trip consisted of organizing the data collected and begin making connections between damages and organizational operability.

 

The analysis of the data collected is still underway. It is hoped that further connections between the physical damages of the buildings and organizations operability will be made. Also of importance for this research is to further understand what specific damages lead to certain safety placard decisions. Understanding the relationship between damage and tagging levels will help stakeholders and building owners in earthquake prone areas understand the risks and outcomes possible for their own buildings and encourage them to take measures to mitigate damages and losses of organization operability in the future. This data will help in assessing resilience in terms of a community’s ability to continue to function post earthquake by providing a way to quantify resilience in terms of building damage and the continued operations of organizations and businesses in the effected area.
